channel.title: Beehives
channel.description: Topics in the 'Beehives' category Welcome to the BEEHIVES collaboration area. If you're a beekeeper, designer, fabricator or materials expert we would appreciate your feedback to improve the next iteration of our beehive designs. To get started, please see the To Do List thread below.

item.title: Current Best Version?
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@mnealon Malcolm Nealon)
item.description:
Malcolm Nealon wrote:

I noticed that there are several versions of a V6 design for the Colorado Top Bar (which I will be making). The manual is for the 5.4 version.

At first glance it looks a bit puzzling which version I should be building. Could there be a stickie referencing the latest prefered design files and manual?

Simply put there can be many design iterations and fine tuning before the design is useful and standardised for "production" and it might be useful for casual or first time browsers to have simple links to the current best design, updated manual and example pictures.

Posts: 3

Participants: 3

Read full topic

item.title: Design Review: Colorado Top Bar v6.6
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@trizcs Tristan Copley Smith)
item.description:
Tristan Copley Smith wrote:

Colorado Top Bar v6.6

To address some functionality issues with the CTB v6.4, @jonathan has made some further changes. This thread intends to review the following changes:

  • Lowered side walls: to allow the top bars to sit along the ridge of the side walls, rather than in a pocket cut in the side walls. Allows for easier removal of the bars for checking brood and honey combs (and extracting honey).

  • Lengthened hive: to allow top bars to swell and contract with changing humidity and still enable them to be easily removed.

Prototype Review:

Generally cut really well - minor issues need to be addressed:

  1. Top bars don't quite fit between ridges of side walls.
  2. Roof beam is loose in the assembly.
  3. Roof assembly (fully assembled roof) no longer has the support of lowered side wall. As a result the roof no longer sits securely and rocks around on the hive.

20150404_114122.jpg2560x1440 797 KB

1. Top bars don't quite fit between ridges of side walls.

20150404_114025.jpg2560x1440 811 KB

2. Roof beam is loose in the assembly.

20150404_114032.jpg2560x1440 898 KB

2. Roof beam is loose in the assembly.

20150404_114054.jpg2560x1440 829 KB

3. Roof assembly (fully assembled roof) no longer has the support of lowered side wall. As a result the roof no longer sits securely and rocks around on the hive.

Posts: 2

Participants: 2

Read full topic

item.title: Flow Hive - new way of extracting honey
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@Jagungal Cormac Farrell)
item.description:
Cormac Farrell wrote:

For those who are interested - this just went live
A new invention from Canberra here in Australia, would actually pair quite well with the sensor packs to create an integrated, low intervention style of beekeeping.

A couple of my mates went to the launch, and this is real, not a trick. Due to the temperature in-hive the honey apparently drains out surprisingly fast.

https://www.indiegogo.com/projects/flow-hive-honey-on-tap-directly-from-your-beehive/x/9972806

http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-02-23/beekeepers-devise-tap-to-collect-honey-without-disturbing-hive/6222728

Enjoy!

Posts: 1

Participants: 1

Read full topic
item.source: Flow Hive - new way of extracting honey

item.title: Langstroth Beehive Development
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@trizcs Tristan Copley Smith)
item.description:
Tristan Copley Smith wrote:

Propose, Collaborate, Develop

The following thread exists to help coordinate collaboration on developing an Open Source Langstroth beehive design.

We have a community-started version here feel free to iterate on it, but introduce yourself and share you skills below first so we can build a team!

Langstroth Beehives are a popular hive style not currently offered by the Open Source Beehives project. There is an obvious demand for this, due to the number of requests we have received!

We are a small, busy team, so this thread aims to bring together collaborators interesting in designing a Langstroth beehive. We encourage collaborators to build off of the work of our project, using similar connectors and design aesthetic developed in our Colorado Top Bar and Barcelona Warré designs. We will support these efforts in any way we can, by promoting and advising on the process.

Any designs developed within this community must be openly licensed - meaning that the designs can be downloaded, improved, and shared by anybody without limitation. They should ultimately be in digital form so they can be downloaded and fabricated easily.

Please introduce yourselves below to get the ball rolling!

langstrothHiveIllus.gif500x538 71.3 KB

Posts: 23

Participants: 10

Read full topic

item.title: Price Competitive Hive Design Proposal
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@AaronM Aaron Makaruk)
item.description:
Aaron Makaruk wrote:

Design Criteria

  1. Affordability - price competitive with low-cost hives
  2. Design for Manufacturing - simplify manufacturing process, use 1/2" bit wherever possible

Pasted image1366x768 373 KB

Design Changes

  1. Starting with the Colorado Top Bar
  2. Remove the hive legs
  3. Lengthen the side walls to nearly 48" - increases hive size for minimal manufacturing time increase.
  4. Remove the roof and use a flat roof design
  5. Change inside profile cuts to use 1/2" bit
  6. Remove the pocket cuts from the sides of the top bars - this is now unnecessary.

Flat Roof

Top Bar Change

Let the top bars sit on top of the side walls for easier access.

Posts: 11

Participants: 5

Read full topic

item.title: Open Source Beehive @ The Franklin Institute
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@wynn_geary Wynn Geary)
item.description:
Wynn Geary wrote:

My name is Wynn Geary, I’m a 17 year old beekeeper from Philadelphia. For my senior capstone project at Science Leadership Academy I've received a grant from The Franklin Institute (a major science museum here in Philly) to start a research apiary in their “science park". We will be setting up the apiary in the Spring with a Barcelona Warre hive. I'm excited to beta test one of the new sensors and help offer feedback. The hive will be very public and we are attempting to grow a community of “vicarious beekeepers” through online interaction with the hive.

I could use some help figuring out the logistics of hooking up a webcam to the window plate of the hive. Does anyone have any ideas about wifi enabled webcams and if the solar power on the OSBH solar panel produce enough energy to power the sensor kit and a webcam?

I'll continue to post as the project develops and I'd love to hear what thoughts or suggestions anyone has about the project. Thanks!

Posts: 1

Participants: 1

Read full topic
item.source: Open Source Beehive @ The Franklin Institute

item.title: Beehive Materials Research
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@trizcs Tristan Copley Smith)
item.description:
Tristan Copley Smith wrote:

Research, Review, Advise

Place Research Here: Plywood Research Spreadsheet

We're always on the lookout for new and interesting materials to use for our beehives. Please help us research and recommend materials below. Below are the list of criteria that materials should meet to be considered:

CRITCAL criteria

  • Available in 4'x8' sheets (thickness can vary)
  • Non-toxic (no toxic glues, famaldahydes, fungasides etc.)
  • Cost efficient (under $100 per sheet)
  • Sustainably sourced
  • CNC routable

IDEAL criteria

  • Water resistant or waterproof
  • Rot resistant
  • Lightweight
  • Recycled or upcycled
  • Reliably flat (not warped)
  • Under $60 per sheet

Posts: 13

Participants: 8

Read full topic

item.title: New Beehive Designs & Proposals
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@trizcs Tristan Copley Smith)
item.description:
Tristan Copley Smith wrote:

Propose, Upload, Discuss

Please propose, upload or discuss any new beehive designs below. New approved designs will become part of the Open Source Beehives family and hosted on our site. Creators will be fully recognised by the project.

If you have a proposal to share or skills to contribute, please team up with other members of the community to make your designs a reality. Our team will support you any way we can, but our time is limited. Let us know if you're looking for collaborators and we can help with outreach.

Any designs associated with OSBH must be licensed under a CC-BY-SA Creative Commons license to be considered.

Posts: 17

Participants: 6

Read full topic

item.title: Beehive Design Review: Colorado Top Bar v6.1
item.author: no-reply@example.com (@AaronM Aaron Makaruk)
item.description:
Aaron Makaruk wrote:

Examine, Review, Advise

Please review our 3D model and photographs and leave any comments, suggestions or recommendations about the hive design below. Read the Colorado Top Bar documentation here.

Colorado Top Bar v6.1 by osbeehives on Sketchfab

Summary of Design Change Suggestions

  • Double follower boards - @nlk3233
  • Place entrance above floor - @BarefootBee
  • Base Plate (floor) - add ventilation/drainage holes - @BarefootBee
  • Insulation above topbars - @BarefootBee
  • Double entrances - front and back of hive - @nlk3233
  • Base Plate (floor) - hinged screen floor - @nlk3233
  • Double floor plates - screen and solid - @AaronM

Posts: 25

Participants: 10

Read full topic
item.source: Beehive Design Review: Colorado Top Bar v6.1
